content.title: Find all real cubic polynomials with zeros 1/2 and -3 +/- 2i
content.solution: The zeros -3 +/- 2i have sum = -3 + 2i - 3 - 2i = -6 and product = (-3 + 2i)(-3 - 2i) = 13. Therefore they come from the quadratic factor x^2 + 6x + 13. 1/2 comes from the linear factor 2x - 1. Therefore P(x) = a(2x - 1)(x^2 + 6x + 13), a != 0.

content.title: Find all real quartic polynomials with zeros 2, -1/3, and -1 +/- sqrt(5)
content.solution: The zeros -1 +/- sqrt(5) have sum = -1 + sqrt(5) - 1 - sqrt(5) = -2 and product = (-1 + sqrt(5))(-1 - sqrt(5)) = -4. Therefore they come from the quadratic factor x^2 + 2x - 4. The zeros 2 and -1/3 come from the linear factors (x - 2) and (3x + 1). Therefore P(x) = a(x - 2)(3x + 1)(x^2 + 2x - 4), a != 0.

content.title: Equality of Polynomials
content.content: Two polynomials are equal if and only if they have the same degree (order) and corresponding terms have equal coefficients. If we know two polynomials are equal, we can equate coefficients to find unknown coefficients. For example, if x^3 - 2x^2 + 3x + 7 = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d, where a, b, c, d in R, then a = 1, b = -2, c = 3, and d = 7.

content.title: Find constants a, b, and c given that: 4x^3 + 10x^2 - x + 15 = (x + 3)(ax^2 + bx + c) for all x
content.solution: 4x^3 + 10x^2 - x + 15 = (x + 3)(ax^2 + bx + c) = ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + 3ax^2 + 3bx + 3c = ax^3 + (3a + b)x^2 + (3b + c)x + 3c. Since this is true for all x, we equate coefficients: a = 4 (x^3 terms), 3a + b = 10 (x^2 terms), 3b + c = -1 (x terms), and 3c = 15 (constant terms). Therefore a = 4 and c = 5. From 12 + b = 10 and 3b + 5 = -1, we get b = -2 in both equations. So, a = 4, b = -2, and c = 5.

content.title: Find constants a and b if z^4 + 9 = (z^2 + az + 3)(z^2 + bz + 3) for all z
content.solution: z^4 + 9 = (z^2 + az + 3)(z^2 + bz + 3) for all z. Expanding: = z^4 + bz^3 + 3z^2 + az^3 + abz^2 + 3az + 3z^2 + 3bz + 9 = z^4 + (a + b)z^3 + (ab + 6)z^2 + (3a + 3b)z + 9 for all z. Equating coefficients gives: a + b = 0 (equation 1), ab + 6 = 0 (equation 2), 3a + 3b = 0 (equation 3). From (1) and (3), b = -a. In (2), a(-a) + 6 = 0, so a^2 = 6. Therefore a = +/- sqrt(6) and so b = -/+ sqrt(6). Thus a = sqrt(6), b = -sqrt(6) or a = -sqrt(6), b = sqrt(6).

content.title: (2x + 3) and (x - 1) are factors of 2x^4 + ax^3 - 3x^2 + bx + 3. Find constants a and b, and all zeros of the polynomial.
content.solution: Since (2x + 3) and (x - 1) are factors, the coefficient of x^4 is 2 * 1 * 1 = 2 and the constant term is 3 * -1 * -1 = 3. So 2x^4 + ax^3 - 3x^2 + bx + 3 = (2x + 3)(x - 1)(x^2 + cx - 1) for some c. Expanding: = (2x^2 + x - 3)(x^2 + cx - 1) = 2x^4 + 2cx^3 - 2x^2 + x^3 + cx^2 - x - 3x^2 - 3cx + 3 = 2x^4 + (2c + 1)x^3 + (c - 5)x^2 + (-1 - 3c)x + 3. Equating coefficients gives 2c + 1 = a, c - 5 = -3, and -1 - 3c = b. Therefore c = 2. So a = 5 and b = -7. Thus P(x) = 2x^4 + 5x^3 - 3x^2 - 7x + 3 = (2x + 3)(x - 1)(x^2 + 2x - 1). Now x^2 + 2x - 1 has zeros (-2 +/- sqrt(4 + 4))/2 = (-2 +/- 2*sqrt(2))/2 = -1 +/- sqrt(2).

content.title: The Remainder Theorem
content.content: Consider the real cubic polynomial P(x) = x^3 + 5x^2 - 11x + 3. If we divide P(x) by x - 2, we find that (x^3 + 5x^2 - 11x + 3)/(x - 2) = x^2 + 7x + 3 + 9/(x - 2). So, when P(x) is divided by x - 2, the remainder is 9. Notice that P(2) = 8 + 20 - 22 + 3 = 9, which is the remainder. By considering other examples like the one above, we formulate the Remainder theorem: When a polynomial P(x) is divided by x - k until a constant remainder R is obtained, then R = P(k).

content.name: Remainder Theorem
content.statement: When a polynomial P(x) is divided by x - k until a constant remainder R is obtained, then R = P(k).
content.proof: By the division algorithm, P(x) = Q(x)(x - k) + R. Letting x = k, P(k) = Q(k) * 0 + R. Therefore P(k) = R.

content.title: Equivalent Statements for Remainder Theorem
content.content: When using the Remainder theorem, it is important to realise that the following statements are equivalent: P(x) = (x - k)Q(x) + R; P(k) = R; P(x) divided by x - k leaves a remainder of R.

content.title: Use the Remainder theorem to find the remainder when x^4 - 3x^3 + x - 4 is divided by x + 2
content.solution: If P(x) = x^4 - 3x^3 + x - 4, then P(-2) = (-2)^4 - 3(-2)^3 + (-2) - 4 = 16 + 24 - 2 - 4 = 34. Therefore when x^4 - 3x^3 + x - 4 is divided by x + 2, the remainder is 34. {Remainder theorem}

content.title: When x^3 + 4x^2 + ax + b is divided by x - 2 the remainder is 20, and when divided by x + 5 the remainder is 6. Find a and b.
content.solution: Let P(x) = x^3 + 4x^2 + ax + b. Therefore P(2) = 20 and P(-5) = 6 {Remainder theorem}. So, (2)^3 + 4(2)^2 + a(2) + b = 20, which gives 8 + 16 + 2a + b = 20, so 2a + b = -4 ... (1). And (-5)^3 + 4(-5)^2 + a(-5) + b = 6, which gives -125 + 100 - 5a + b = 6, so -5a + b = 31 ... (2). Solving simultaneously: 2a + b = -4 {(1)} and 5a - b = -31 {-(2)}. Adding, 7a = -35, so a = -5. Substituting a = -5 into (1), 2(-5) + b = -4, so b = 6.

content.title: When P(x) is divided by x^2 - 3x + 7, the quotient is x^2 + x - 1 and the remainder R(x) is unknown. When P(x) is divided by x - 2 the remainder is 29. When P(x) is divided by x + 1 the remainder is -16. Find R(x) in the form ax + b.
content.solution: When the divisor is x^2 - 3x + 7, P(x) = (x^2 + x - 1)(x^2 - 3x + 7) + ax + b, where Q(x) = x^2 + x - 1, D(x) = x^2 - 3x + 7, and R(x) = ax + b. Now P(2) = 29 {Remainder theorem}. So (2^2 + 2 - 1)(2^2 - 6 + 7) + 2a + b = 29, giving (5)(5) + 2a + b = 29, so 2a + b = 4 ... (1). Also, P(-1) = -16 {Remainder theorem}. So ((-1)^2 + (-1) - 1)((-1)^2 - 3(-1) + 7) + (-a + b) = -16, giving (-1)(11) - a + b = -16, so -a + b = -5 ... (2). Solving (1) and (2) simultaneously gives a = 3 and b = -2. Therefore R(x) = 3x - 2.

content.name: Factor Theorem
content.statement: For any polynomial P(x), k is a zero of P(x) if and only if (x - k) is a factor of P(x).
content.proof: k is a zero of P(x) <=> P(k) = 0 {definition of a zero} <=> R = 0 {Remainder theorem} <=> P(x) = Q(x)(x - k) {division algorithm} <=> (x - k) is a factor of P(x) {definition of a factor}
content.note: The Factor theorem says that if 2 is a zero of P(x) then (x - 2) is a factor of P(x), and vice versa.

content.title: Find k given that (x - 2) is a factor of x^3 + kx^2 - 3x + 6. Hence fully factorise x^3 + kx^2 - 3x + 6.
content.solution: Let P(x) = x^3 + kx^2 - 3x + 6. Since (x - 2) is a factor, P(2) = 0 {Factor theorem}. Therefore (2)^3 + k(2)^2 - 3(2) + 6 = 0, so 8 + 4k = 0, hence k = -2. We now use division to find the other factors of P(x): Using division algorithm or synthetic division: x^3 - 2x^2 - 3x + 6 divided by (x - 2) gives x^2 - 3. Therefore P(x) = (x - 2)(x^2 - 3) = (x - 2)(x + sqrt(3))(x - sqrt(3)).

content.title: Determine whether: a) (x - 2) is a factor of x^3 + 3x^2 - 13x + 6, b) (x + 3) is a factor of x^3 - 8x + 7

solution.work: Let P(x) = x^3 + 3x^2 - 13x + 6. Therefore P(2) = (2)^3 + 3(2)^2 - 13(2) + 6 = 8 + 12 - 26 + 6 = 0. Since P(2) = 0, (x - 2) is a factor of x^3 + 3x^2 - 13x + 6. {Factor theorem}

Let P(x) = x^3 - 8x + 7. Therefore P(-3) = (-3)^3 - 8(-3) + 7 = -27 + 24 + 7 = 4. Since P(-3) != 0, (x + 3) is not a factor of x^3 - 8x + 7. {Factor theorem}. When x^3 - 8x + 7 is divided by (x + 3), a remainder of 4 is left over.

content.title: Find c given that (x + 2) is a factor of x^3 + 7x^2 + cx - 12
content.solution: Let P(x) = x^3 + 7x^2 + cx - 12. Now P(-2) = 0 {Factor theorem}. Therefore (-2)^3 + 7(-2)^2 + c(-2) - 12 = 0, so -8 + 28 - 2c - 12 = 0, hence 8 = 2c, and c = 4.
